message: /* The necessity of distinguishing between the new wave, new romantic, and new pop genres */ new section

The idea of 'synth-driven new wave' in the mid-80s is anachronistic and would have been meaningless to a Brit at the time. We all know what's going on here: he's talking about synth-pop, which has been incorrectly conflated with 'new wave' by a number of American sources. I know this, you know this (at least you ought to by now), we all know this. There's no reason to mislead the readers with vague and incorrect terminology - the New Romantics made synthpop, not 'New Wave music'.

'Actual true music genre'...well yes, but that doesn't mean it has anything to with Spandau Ballet (it doesn't). They were a pop band, and new wave was, in fact, a period of pop history, one which preceded them. Sure, they could have continued to make music in a similar style to late 70s new wave, but...why would they? They were 'futurists', New Romantics, who took from Euro electro-disco (and then soul), not New Wavers.

Little known by whom? If the existence of new pop is little known, then it is Wikipedia's job as an encyclopedia to provide that information to its readers, not mislead them with incorrect terminology. The fact that new wave has 'always remained first on the genre list' is all the more reason for it to be swiftly corrected. If you continue your edits spreading disinformation, I am prepared to bring in citations from Dave Rimmer's "Like Punk Never Happned" that more or less disprove all you say.

'New Wave' shouldn't even be listed here at all - it was a movement of the late 70s and very early 80s, when Joy Division, not New Order, were around. No English person called New Order 'new wave' during the 80s - new wave was over by then. They were post-punk, techno-pop, electro rock, you name it, but 'new wave' is just wrong.

He's right. Marquee Moon was recorded in 1976, so by any reasonable chronology it's not 'post-punk'. New Wave existed alongside punk in the mid-late 70s while post-punk came after punk (hence the name), so to say this influenced 'new wave' in the 80s while being a 'post-punk' record from early 1977 is incoherent.
